document_info.title: Prevention of Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism – Holders of Payment Services Licence (Specified Payment Services)
document_info.legal_basis: Financial Services and Markets Act 2022, Section 16
document_info.applicable_to: Payment service providers licensed under Payment Services Act 2019

clause_5.title: Assessing Risks and Applying a Risk-Based Approach
clause_5.description: Payment service providers must identify, assess, and understand their money laundering and terrorism financing risks across customers, jurisdictions, operations, and products/services.

5.1.requirement: Payment service provider shall take appropriate steps to identify, assess and understand its money laundering and terrorism financing risks in relation to:
risk_factors: The countries or jurisdictions its customers are from or in
The countries or jurisdictions the payment service provider has operations in
The products, services, transactions and delivery channels of the payment service provider

components.5.2.a: Documenting the payment service provider's risk assessments
components.5.2.b: Considering all the relevant risk factors before determining the level of overall risk and the appropriate type and extent of mitigation to be applied
components.5.2.c: Keeping the payment service provider's risk assessments up-to-date
components.5.2.d: Having appropriate mechanisms to provide its risk assessment information to the Authority

requirements.5.3.a: Develop and implement policies, procedures and controls, which are approved by senior management, to enable effective management and mitigation of identified risks
requirements.5.3.b: Monitor the implementation of those policies, procedures and controls, and enhance them if necessary
requirements.5.3.c: Perform enhanced measures where higher risks are identified
requirements.5.3.d: Ensure that measures address the risk assessment and guidance from the Authority or other relevant authorities

clause_5.summary: This clause establishes the foundation for risk-based AML/CFT compliance by requiring PSPs to systematically identify, document, and mitigate ML/TF risks across all dimensions of their business. It mandates ongoing risk assessment and senior management ownership of risk mitigation strategies.
clause_5.supplementary_info: Risk assessments must be dynamic and regularly updated. The risk-based approach allows PSPs to allocate resources proportionately to identified risks, applying enhanced measures where risks are higher and simplified measures where risks are demonstrably lower. Risk factors include customer type, geographic exposure, product complexity, and delivery channels.
clause_5.validation_approach: Validate that high-risk customers (high customer_risk_rating, customer_is_pep=true, high-risk countries) have edd_required and edd_performed flags set appropriately. Check that product_type and channel combinations align with documented risk assessments.

clause_7.title: Customer Due Diligence (CDD)
clause_7.description: Comprehensive requirements for identifying customers, verifying identities, understanding beneficial ownership, and monitoring ongoing business relationships.

7.1.title: Anonymous or Fictitious Account
7.1.requirement: No payment service provider shall open or maintain an anonymous account or an account in a fictitious name
7.1.validation_approach: Check for null, blank, generic placeholder names (e.g., 'Anonymous', 'Unknown', 'N/A'), or systematic patterns indicating fictitious identities.

7.2.title: Where There Are Reasonable Grounds for Suspicion
7.2.requirement: Prior to establishing business relations or undertaking transactions, if there are reasonable grounds to suspect proceeds of crime or terrorism financing, the PSP shall not proceed and must file an STR
7.2.validation_approach: Validate that transactions do not proceed when suspicion_determined_datetime is populated before booking_datetime. Check sanctions_screening results.

7.3.title: When CDD is to be Performed

triggers.7.3.a: Establishing business relations with any customer
triggers.7.3.b: Cross-border wire transfer for non-relationship customer
triggers.7.3.c: Cross-border money transfer service for non-relationship customer
triggers.7.3.d: Transaction exceeding S$5,000 for non-relationship customer (except specified money-changing from identifiable source)
triggers.7.3.e: Suspicion of money laundering or terrorism financing
triggers.7.3.f: Doubts about veracity or adequacy of previously obtained information

7.3.validation_approach: For transactions >S$5,000 or cross-border transfers, validate that kyc_last_completed is populated and recent. Check that all high-value or cross-border transactions have associated customer_id with completed CDD.

7.4.title: Transaction Aggregation
7.4.requirement: Where PSP suspects multiple transactions are related, linked or deliberately structured to evade measures, shall treat as single transaction and aggregate values
7.4.validation_approach: Identify patterns of multiple transactions just below thresholds within short timeframes from same customer/accounts. Check if daily_cash_total_customer and daily_cash_txn_count indicate structuring patterns.

7.26_to_7.33.title: Ongoing Monitoring
7.26_to_7.33.requirement: PSP shall monitor business relations on an ongoing basis, scrutinize transactions to ensure consistency with knowledge of customer, business and risk profile

sub_requirements.7.27: Monitor conduct of customer's account and scrutinize transactions throughout business relations to ensure consistency with knowledge of customer, business and risk profile, and where appropriate, source of funds
sub_requirements.7.28: Pay special attention to all complex, unusually large or unusual patterns of transactions that have no apparent or visible economic or lawful purpose
sub_requirements.7.29: Put in place adequate systems and processes to monitor business relations and detect and report suspicious, complex, unusually large or unusual patterns
sub_requirements.7.31: Ensure CDD data is relevant and kept up-to-date by undertaking reviews, particularly for higher risk categories
sub_requirements.7.32: Where reasonable grounds for suspicion exist and customer is retained, substantiate and document reasons, subject customer to enhanced ongoing monitoring
sub_requirements.7.33: For higher risk customers under 7.32, perform enhanced CDD including obtaining senior management approval to retain customer

7.26_to_7.33.validation_approach: Check that kyc_last_completed is within acceptable periods based on customer_risk_rating (higher risk = more frequent reviews). Validate that high-risk customers have edd_performed=true. Flag large/unusual transactions where narrative or purpose is vague or inconsistent with customer profile.

7.51_to_7.54.title: Screening
7.51_to_7.54.requirement: PSP shall screen customers, appointed persons, connected parties, and beneficial owners against relevant ML/TF information sources and lists provided by authorities

timing.7.52.a: When, or as soon as reasonably practicable after, establishing business relations
timing.7.52.b: Before cross-border wire transfer for non-relationship customer
timing.7.52.c: Before cross-border money transfer for non-relationship customer
timing.7.52.d: Before transaction exceeding S$5,000 for non-relationship customer (except specified money-changing from identifiable source)
timing.7.52.e: On a periodic basis after establishing business relations
timing.7.52.f: When there are changes or updates to lists or customer information

7.51_to_7.54.wire_transfer_screening: Screen all wire transfer originators and beneficiaries against lists provided by Authority or relevant authorities (7.53)
7.51_to_7.54.documentation: Results of screening and assessment must be documented (7.54)
7.51_to_7.54.validation_approach: Validate that sanctions_screening is populated for all transactions. Check that customer_is_pep is determined and documented. Cross-reference screening results with customer_risk_rating escalations.

clause_7.summary: Clause 7 forms the core of AML/CFT compliance, establishing detailed requirements for customer identification, verification, beneficial ownership determination, ongoing monitoring, and sanctions screening. It requires PSPs to know their customers, understand the nature and purpose of business relationships, and maintain current information throughout the relationship lifecycle.
clause_7.supplementary_info: CDD is triggered not just at onboarding but at multiple points including threshold transactions, cross-border activities, and when suspicions arise. The clause emphasizes a risk-based approach where enhanced measures apply to higher-risk situations and simplified measures may apply to demonstrably lower-risk scenarios (see Clause 8). Ongoing monitoring is not a one-time exercise but a continuous process of transaction scrutiny and periodic CDD refresh.

clause_8.title: Simplified Customer Due Diligence
clause_8.description: Conditions under which payment service providers may apply simplified CDD measures for lower-risk customers and transactions.

8.1.requirement: PSP may perform simplified CDD where either:

conditions.8.1.a: Customer is one for whom PSP only effects cross-border wire transfers that are solely for payment of goods or services and funded from identifiable source
conditions.8.1.b: PSP is satisfied that risks of ML/TF are low

8.4.title: Restrictions on Simplified CDD
8.4.requirement: PSP shall not perform simplified CDD where:

restrictions.8.4.a: Transactions by customer (other than payment account to customer's bank account) in any one year cumulatively exceed S$20,000
restrictions.8.4.b: Customer or beneficial owner is from or in a country/jurisdiction for which FATF has called for countermeasures
restrictions.8.4.c: Customer or beneficial owner is from or in a country/jurisdiction known to have inadequate AML/CFT measures
restrictions.8.4.d: PSP suspects money laundering or terrorism financing is involved

clause_8.summary: Simplified CDD allows resource-efficient processing of demonstrably lower-risk customers and transactions, but with strict boundaries to prevent abuse. The S$20,000 annual threshold and geographic restrictions ensure that simplified measures only apply to genuinely low-risk scenarios.
clause_8.supplementary_info: Simplified CDD is not 'no CDD' - it means proportionate measures based on documented low-risk assessment. PSPs must still identify customers and understand transaction purposes, but may reduce the extent of verification or ongoing monitoring compared to standard CDD. The clause recognizes that certain financial institutions (Appendix 2) and payment patterns present lower inherent ML/TF risk.
clause_8.validation_approach: Identify customers with low customer_risk_rating and validate that cumulative annual transaction volumes don't exceed S$20,000. Check that customers from high-risk jurisdictions are not classified as low-risk. Validate that transactions coded as goods/services payments have appropriate purpose codes.

clause_9.title: Enhanced Customer Due Diligence
clause_9.description: Requirements for higher-risk scenarios including politically exposed persons (PEPs) and other elevated ML/TF risk situations.

9.2.title: PEP Determination
9.2.requirement: PSP shall implement appropriate internal risk management systems, policies, procedures and controls to determine if a customer, appointed person, connected party or beneficial owner is a PEP, or family member or close associate of a PEP

9.3.title: Enhanced CDD for PEPs
9.3.requirement: In addition to standard CDD, PSP shall perform enhanced CDD for PEPs, their family members and close associates:

measures.9.3.a: Obtain approval from senior management to establish or continue business relations or undertake transactions
measures.9.3.b: Establish, by appropriate and reasonable means, the source of wealth and source of funds of customer and beneficial owners
measures.9.3.c: Conduct enhanced monitoring of business relations, increasing degree and nature of monitoring to determine whether transactions appear unusual or suspicious

9.6_to_9.8.title: Other Higher Risk Categories
9.6_to_9.8.requirement: PSP shall implement systems to determine if business relations or transactions present higher ML/TF risk

higher_risk_circumstances.9.7.a: Customer or beneficial owner from/in jurisdiction for which FATF has called for countermeasures - shall treat as higher risk
higher_risk_circumstances.9.7.b: Customer or beneficial owner from/in jurisdiction with inadequate AML/CFT measures - shall assess whether presents higher risk
higher_risk_circumstances.9.7.c: Customer is legal person for which PSP cannot establish ongoing/visible operation, economic/business purpose for structure, or substantive financial activity - shall assess whether presents higher risk

9.6_to_9.8.enhanced_measures: PSP shall perform appropriate enhanced CDD from paragraph 9.3 for customers determined or notified as presenting higher ML/TF risk (9.8)

clause_9.summary: Enhanced CDD applies a heightened level of scrutiny to relationships and transactions that present elevated ML/TF risks. PEPs receive special attention due to their positions of influence and potential exposure to corruption. Other risk factors include adverse jurisdictions, opaque corporate structures, and unusual transaction patterns.
clause_9.supplementary_info: PEPs are categorized as domestic, foreign, or international organization PEPs. A risk-based approach may be applied to domestic and international organization PEPs who have stepped down from prominent functions (9.5), but foreign PEPs always require enhanced measures. Source of wealth (accumulated assets) differs from source of funds (specific transaction funding) - both must be established for PEPs. Enhanced monitoring means more frequent reviews, lower thresholds for alerts, and greater scrutiny of transaction purposes.
clause_9.validation_approach: Validate that all customers with customer_is_pep=true have edd_required=true and edd_performed=true. Check that sow_documented=true for PEPs. Validate that customers from FATF countermeasure jurisdictions have high customer_risk_rating and edd_performed=true. Flag customers with vague business descriptions or unclear transaction purposes for enhanced review.

clause_10.title: Foreign Currency Exchange Transactions
clause_10.description: Application of CDD requirements to foreign exchange transactions equal to or exceeding S$20,000.

10.1.requirement: Where FX transaction value equals or exceeds S$20,000, PSP shall comply with paragraphs 7, 8, and 9 in relation to the relevant FX counterparty as if they were a customer

10.3.requirement: In addition to CDD measures, PSP shall inquire into background and purpose of every FX transaction equal to or exceeding S$20,000 and document findings

clause_10.summary: FX transactions above the S$20,000 threshold require full CDD treatment of the FX counterparty, recognizing that currency exchange can be used for layering illicit funds or obscuring transaction trails.
clause_10.supplementary_info: The S$20,000 threshold aligns with other transaction monitoring thresholds in the notice. FX transactions present ML/TF risk because they can be used to move value across borders, complicate audit trails, and exploit exchange rate fluctuations. Understanding the purpose is critical as legitimate FX needs differ from suspicious patterns (e.g., frequent back-and-forth exchanges with no apparent commercial purpose).
clause_10.validation_approach: Filter transactions where fx_indicator=true and amount>=20000. Validate that fx_counterparty is identified and CDD performed. Check that purpose is documented in swift_f70_purpose or narrative. Flag transactions with unusual fx_spread_bps or frequent currency round-tripping patterns.

clause_11.title: Issuance of Bearer Negotiable Instruments and Restriction of Cash Payout
clause_11.description: Prohibitions and restrictions on bearer instruments and large cash payouts to prevent anonymity and enhance traceability.

11.1.title: Prohibition of Bearer Negotiable Instruments
11.1.requirement: No PSP shall make payment in the form of bearer negotiable instrument to any recipient for money-changing, cross-border transfers, domestic transfers, payment account withdrawals, or FX transactions

11.2.title: Restriction on Cash Payouts
11.2.requirement: No PSP shall pay cash in amount equal to or exceeding S$20,000 to any recipient for cross-border transfers, domestic transfers, payment account withdrawals, or FX transactions

11.3.title: Transaction Aggregation
11.3.requirement: Where PSP suspects transactions are related, linked or deliberately structured to evade paragraph 11.2 measures, shall treat as single transaction and aggregate values

11.4.title: Crossed Cheque Exception
11.4.requirement: PSP may make payment of S$20,000 and above by crossed cheque if:
conditions: Cheque is crossed and made payable to customer who is account holder with bank in Singapore
PSP maintains register of all crossed cheques issued with corresponding transaction reference numbers

clause_11.summary: This clause eliminates bearer instruments (untraceable payment forms) and restricts large cash payouts, forcing transactions above S$20,000 into traceable channels. This significantly enhances the audit trail and makes it harder to move large sums anonymously.
clause_11.supplementary_info: Bearer negotiable instruments pass ownership by physical delivery without endorsement, making them effectively anonymous and untraceable - ideal for money laundering. The S$20,000 cash restriction recognizes that cash transactions above this threshold present heightened ML/TF risk due to anonymity. Crossed cheques provide traceability as they must be deposited into a bank account. The structuring provision (11.3) prevents evasion through multiple smaller transactions.
clause_11.validation_approach: Identify cash transactions (cash_id_verified populated) where amount>=20000 - these should be flagged as violations unless properly documented exceptions. Analyze patterns in daily_cash_total_customer and daily_cash_txn_count to detect structuring where multiple cash transactions just below S$20,000 occur within short timeframes for same customer.

clause_15.title: Wire Transfers
clause_15.description: Comprehensive requirements for information to accompany wire transfers, implementing FATF's 'Travel Rule' to ensure traceability.

15.3.title: Identification and Recording
15.3.requirement: Before effecting or arranging wire transfer, ordering institution shall:
requirements: Identify the wire transfer originator and take reasonable measures to verify identity (if not already done per paragraph 7)
Record adequate details to permit reconstruction, including date, currency type and amount, and value date

15.4_and_15.5.title: Cross-Border Wire Transfers ≤ S$1,500
15.4_and_15.5.requirement: For cross-border wire transfers ≤S$1,500, ordering institution shall include in message:
required_information: Wire transfer originator's account number (or unique transaction reference number if no account)
Wire transfer beneficiary's account number (or unique transaction reference number if no account)
15.4_and_15.5.exception: May include only unique transaction reference number and beneficiary information to intermediary institution in Singapore, provided information can be provided within 3 business days upon request (immediately for law enforcement)

15.6_and_15.8.title: Cross-Border Wire Transfers > S$1,500
15.6_and_15.8.requirement: For cross-border wire transfers >S$1,500, ordering institution shall identify and verify originator identity and include all information from 15.4 plus:
additional_required_information: Wire transfer originator's residential address (or registered/business address if not natural person), OR
Wire transfer originator's unique identification number (ID card, passport, incorporation number, etc.), OR
Date and place of birth, incorporation or registration of originator
15.6_and_15.8.batch_transfers: Where multiple transfers from single originator are bundled in batch file, batch must contain verified originator information and beneficiary information, fully traceable within beneficiary jurisdiction (15.7)
15.6_and_15.8.exception: May include only unique transaction reference number and beneficiary information to intermediary institution in Singapore, provided full information can be provided within 3 business days upon request (immediately for law enforcement) (15.8)

15.9.title: Domestic Wire Transfers
15.9.requirement: For domestic wire transfers, ordering institution shall either:
15.9.option_a: Include in message: originator name, originator account number (or unique reference), and one of: address, unique ID number, or date/place of birth/incorporation
15.9.option_b: Include only originator account number (or unique reference), provided details can be provided within 3 business days upon request (immediately for law enforcement) and details permit tracing back to originator and beneficiary

requirements.15.12: Take reasonable measures to identify cross-border wire transfers lacking required originator or beneficiary information
requirements.15.13: For cross-border transfers where beneficiary institution pays out cash/cash equivalent in Singapore, must identify and verify beneficiary identity if not previously verified
requirements.15.14: Implement risk-based policies for determining when to execute, reject, or suspend wire transfer lacking required information and appropriate follow-up action
requirements.15.15: Where PSP controls both ordering and beneficiary institution, take into account all information from both to determine if STR required, and file STR in affected jurisdictions

requirements.15.16: Retain all information accompanying wire transfer
requirements.15.17: Provide information accompanying wire transfer to next intermediary or beneficiary institution
requirements.15.18: Where technical limitations prevent required information from remaining with related domestic wire transfer, keep record for at least 5 years
requirements.15.19: Take reasonable measures consistent with straight-through processing to identify cross-border wire transfers lacking required information
requirements.15.20: Implement risk-based policies for determining when to execute, reject, or suspend wire transfer lacking required information

clause_15.summary: Clause 15 implements the FATF Travel Rule, requiring comprehensive originator and beneficiary information to accompany wire transfers. The requirements vary by transfer amount and type (cross-border vs. domestic), with stricter requirements for larger transfers. This ensures traceability and enables authorities to follow the money trail in ML/TF investigations.
clause_15.supplementary_info: The Travel Rule addresses the risk that wire transfers can rapidly move funds across borders with limited transparency. Different thresholds (S$1,500) recognize that higher-value transfers warrant more complete information. Intermediary institutions play a critical role in preserving information integrity through the payment chain. The ability to delay provision of full information (with ability to provide upon request) balances operational efficiency with compliance requirements. Beneficiary institutions have special responsibilities when paying out cash, as this is a critical control point where funds enter the physical realm.
clause_15.validation_approach: For cross-border wire transfers (originator_country != beneficiary_country), validate that travel_rule_complete=true. Check swift_f50_present and swift_f59_present flags for SWIFT messages. For amounts >S$1,500, verify that originator and beneficiary details are complete. Flag transactions where required fields (originator_name, originator_account, beneficiary_name, beneficiary_account) are missing or incomplete.

clause_16.title: Record Keeping
clause_16.description: Requirements for maintaining records of all data, documents and information obtained or produced to meet AML/CFT obligations.

16.1_and_16.2.requirement: PSP shall prepare, maintain and retain records of all data, documents and information required under this Notice such that:
purposes: All requirements imposed by law (including this Notice) are met
Any individual transaction can be reconstructed (including amount and currency type) to provide evidence for prosecution
Authority, relevant authorities, and internal/external auditors can review business relations, transactions, records and CDD information, and assess compliance
PSP can satisfy inquiries or orders from relevant authorities within reasonable time

16.3.title: Retention Periods
16.3.requirement: PSP shall comply with following record retention periods:

periods.16.3.a: For CDD information relating to business relations, wire transfers, transactions without account being opened (except specified money-changing), account files, business correspondence and analysis results: at least 5 years following termination of business relations or completion of wire transfers or transactions
periods.16.3.b: For data, documents and information relating to a transaction, including information needed to explain and reconstruct transaction: at least 5 years following completion of transaction

16.4.requirement: PSP may retain records as originals or copies, in paper or electronic form or on microfilm, provided they are admissible as evidence in Singapore court of law

16.5.requirement: PSP shall retain records on all business relations or transactions pertaining to matter under investigation or that has been subject of STR, in accordance with any request or order from STRO or other relevant authorities

clause_16.summary: Comprehensive record-keeping ensures that AML/CFT compliance activities are documented and transaction trails can be reconstructed years after the fact. The 5-year retention period aligns with international standards and statute of limitations for many financial crimes.
clause_16.supplementary_info: Record-keeping serves multiple purposes: demonstrating compliance during audits/inspections, supporting internal investigations, providing evidence for law enforcement, and enabling transaction reconstruction. Records must be accessible and in a format that can be produced upon request. Electronic records are acceptable if they meet evidentiary standards. The requirement to retain records beyond 5 years for matters under investigation prevents destruction of evidence.
clause_16.validation_approach: While record retention is primarily a systems/archival function, validate that kyc_last_completed dates exist and are within expected timeframes. For transactions with suspicion_determined_datetime populated, ensure appropriate flags indicate ongoing retention requirements. This is partially relevant as the provided columns don't capture the full scope of record-keeping metadata.

clause_18.title: Suspicious Transactions Reporting
clause_18.description: Requirements for identifying, documenting, and reporting suspicious transactions to STRO.

18.1.requirement: PSP shall implement appropriate internal policies, procedures and controls for meeting STR obligations under CDSA and TSOFA, including:

requirements.18.1.a: Establish a single reference point within the organisation to whom all employees and officers are instructed to promptly refer all transactions suspected of being connected with ML/TF, for possible referral to STRO via STRs
requirements.18.1.b: Keep records of all transactions referred to STRO, together with all internal findings and analysis done in relation to them

18.2.requirement: PSP shall promptly submit reports on suspicious transactions (including attempted transactions), regardless of the amount of the transaction, to STRO, and extend a copy to the Authority upon request

18.3.requirement: PSP shall consider if circumstances are suspicious so as to warrant filing STR and document the basis for its determination, including where:
circumstances: PSP is unable to complete CDD measures required by paragraphs 7, 8 and 9
Customer is reluctant, unable or unwilling to provide requested information, or decides to withdraw pending application/transaction, or terminate existing business relations

18.4.requirement: Where PSP forms suspicion of ML/TF and reasonably believes that performing CDD measures will tip-off customer, appointed person, connected party or beneficial owner, PSP may stop performing those measures. PSP shall document the basis for its assessment and file an STR

clause_18.summary: STR reporting is a critical component of the AML/CFT framework, requiring PSPs to promptly report suspicious activity regardless of transaction amount. The clause recognizes that suspicion can arise from customer behavior (reluctance to provide information, sudden withdrawal) as well as transaction patterns. It balances the need to complete CDD with the risk of alerting criminals through tipping-off.
clause_18.supplementary_info: Suspicious transactions are not limited to those that meet monetary thresholds - even small transactions can be suspicious if they fit unusual patterns or involve suspicious parties. The 'single reference point' (often called a Money Laundering Reporting Officer or MLRO) ensures consistent evaluation of suspicions. Documentation is critical - PSPs must be able to explain why they did or didn't file an STR. The tipping-off prohibition means PSPs cannot inform customers that they've been reported or that an investigation is underway.
clause_18.validation_approach: Validate that transactions with suspicion_determined_datetime populated have appropriate risk ratings and screening results documented. Check for patterns indicating suspicious behavior: incomplete KYC (kyc_last_completed is null or very old), failed sanctions screening, vague or inconsistent purpose narratives, unusual amounts for customer profile. Flag transactions where customer_id shows history of incomplete CDD attempts.

clause_19.title: Internal Policies, Compliance, Audit and Training
clause_19.description: Requirements for establishing comprehensive AML/CFT governance framework including policies, compliance function, audit, employee screening, and training.

19.1_and_19.2.requirement: PSP shall develop and implement adequate internal policies, procedures and controls, taking into consideration ML/TF risks and size of business, to help prevent ML/TF and communicate these to employees. Policies must meet all requirements of this Notice

19.2B_to_19.2I.title: Group Policy
19.2B_to_19.2I.requirement: PSP incorporated in Singapore shall develop group policy on AML/CFT meeting all requirements of this Notice and extend to all branches and subsidiaries in financial group

key_requirements.19.2C: Where branch/subsidiary in jurisdiction with FATF countermeasures or inadequate AML/CFT measures, ensure group policy is strictly observed
key_requirements.19.2D_to_19.2F: Develop group policies for sharing information (with adequate confidentiality safeguards) for CDD and ML/TF risk management purposes, including providing customer, account, and transaction information to group-level compliance, audit, and AML/CFT functions. Information includes analysis of unusual transactions
key_requirements.19.2G: Where host jurisdiction requirements differ from Singapore, apply higher of two standards to extent host law permits
key_requirements.19.2H: Where host law conflicts with Singapore law preventing higher standard, apply additional measures to manage ML/TF risks, report to Authority and comply with further directions
key_requirements.19.2I: Singapore branch of PSP incorporated outside Singapore shall share customer, account, and transaction information within financial group when necessary for ML/TF risk management, including analysis of unusual transactions

19.3_and_19.4.title: Compliance
19.3_and_19.4.requirement: PSP shall develop appropriate compliance management arrangements, including:
requirements: Appointment of AML/CFT compliance officer at management level (19.3)
Ensure compliance officer and assistants are suitably qualified, have adequate resources and timely access to all customer records and relevant information required to discharge functions (19.4)

19.5.title: Audit
19.5.requirement: PSP shall maintain audit function that is adequately resourced and independent, and able to regularly assess effectiveness of internal policies, procedures and controls, and compliance with regulatory requirements

19.6.title: Employee Hiring
19.6.requirement: PSP shall have in place screening procedures to ensure high standards when hiring employees and appointing officers

19.7.title: Training
19.7.requirement: PSP shall take all appropriate steps to ensure employees and officers (whether in Singapore or elsewhere) are regularly and appropriately trained on:
training_topics: AML/CFT laws and regulations, and in particular, CDD measures, and detecting and reporting of suspicious transactions
Prevailing techniques, methods and trends in ML/TF
PSP's internal AML/CFT policies, procedures and controls, and roles and responsibilities of employees and officers in combating ML/TF

clause_19.summary: This clause establishes the governance framework for AML/CFT compliance, requiring PSPs to build comprehensive control environments with clear accountability, independent oversight, qualified personnel, and ongoing training. The group policy requirements ensure consistent standards across international operations while recognizing jurisdictional differences.
clause_19.supplementary_info: Effective AML/CFT compliance requires 'three lines of defense': (1) business units implementing policies, (2) compliance function providing oversight and guidance, and (3) audit function providing independent assurance. The compliance officer role is critical - this person must have sufficient seniority, resources, and access to be effective. Training must be regular and role-specific - frontline staff need different training than senior management or compliance specialists. Group policies ensure that international operations don't create weak links in the compliance chain.
clause_19.validation_approach: Internal policies, compliance functions, audit, and training are governance and organizational matters that cannot be validated from transaction-level data. These requirements are assessed through policy reviews, organizational charts, training records, and audit reports - not from the transaction dataset provided.

clause_12.title: Reliance on Third Parties
clause_12.description: Conditions under which PSPs may rely on third parties to perform CDD measures, while retaining ultimate responsibility.

12.2.requirement: PSP may rely on third party to perform CDD measures (paragraphs 7, 8, 9) if following requirements met:

requirements.12.2.a: PSP is satisfied that third party is subject to and supervised for AML/CFT compliance consistent with FATF standards, and has adequate AML/CFT measures in place
requirements.12.2.b: PSP takes appropriate steps to identify, assess and understand ML/TF risks particular to countries/jurisdictions that third party operates in
requirements.12.2.c: Third party is not one which PSPs have been specifically precluded by Authority from relying upon
requirements.12.2.d: Third party is able and willing to provide, without delay, upon PSP's request, any data, documents or information obtained regarding CDD measures

12.3.requirement: No PSP shall rely on third party to conduct review of transactions undertaken without account being opened or ongoing monitoring of business relations

12.5.requirement: Notwithstanding reliance upon third party, PSP shall remain responsible for its AML/CFT obligations in this Notice

clause_12.summary: Third-party reliance allows operational efficiency by avoiding duplication of CDD work, but PSPs cannot outsource their responsibility. They must ensure third parties meet FATF standards and can provide information upon demand. Critical functions like transaction monitoring cannot be delegated.
clause_12.supplementary_info: Third-party reliance is common in correspondent banking, agent relationships, and financial group structures. The key principle is that reliance is permissible for identification and verification, but not for ongoing monitoring and transaction review. PSPs must conduct due diligence on the third party itself before relying on them. If a third party's CDD work proves inadequate, the PSP bears the regulatory consequences.
clause_12.validation_approach: Third-party reliance is an operational arrangement that cannot be validated from transaction data alone. Assessment requires reviewing third-party agreements, due diligence documentation, and information-sharing protocols - not transactional records.

clause_13.title: Correspondent Accounts
clause_13.description: Enhanced due diligence requirements for correspondent banking relationships due to their ML/TF risk profile.

13.3.title: Measures When Providing Correspondent Services
13.3.requirement: PSP providing correspondent account services or similar services shall, in addition to CDD measures, perform:

measures.13.3.a: Assess suitability of respondent financial institution by: (i) gathering adequate information about respondent's business, management, major activities and countries of operation; (ii) determining reputation and quality of supervision, including whether subject of ML/TF investigation or regulatory action; (iii) assessing respondent's AML/CFT controls for adequacy and effectiveness
measures.13.3.b: Clearly understand and document respective AML/CFT responsibilities of PSP and respondent financial institution
measures.13.3.c: Obtain senior management approval before providing correspondent services to new financial institution

13.4.title: Payable-Through Accounts
13.4.requirement: Where correspondent services involve payable-through account, PSP shall be satisfied that:
requirements: Respondent financial institution has performed appropriate CDD measures at least equivalent to paragraph 7 on third party having direct access to payable-through account
Respondent financial institution is able to perform ongoing monitoring and is willing and able to provide CDD information to PSP upon request

13.5.title: Measures When Receiving Correspondent Services
13.5.requirement: PSP receiving correspondent account services or similar services shall perform same enhanced measures as 13.3 on correspondent financial institution

13.7.requirement: No PSP shall enter into or continue correspondent relationship with financial institution that does not have adequate controls against ML/TF, is not effectively supervised, or is a shell financial institution

13.8.requirement: PSP shall take appropriate measures to satisfy itself that its respondent or correspondent financial institutions do not permit their accounts to be used by shell financial institutions

clause_13.summary: Correspondent banking presents heightened ML/TF risk because it can provide indirect access to payment systems and creates complex chains of transactions. Enhanced due diligence, senior management approval, and prohibition on shell banks are critical controls.
clause_13.supplementary_info: Correspondent banking has been exploited for large-scale money laundering because it can enable access to financial systems without direct oversight. Shell banks (banks with no physical presence and not part of regulated groups) are particularly high-risk and are prohibited. Payable-through accounts are especially risky as they allow respondent's customers direct access to the correspondent's systems. The requirement to understand and document AML/CFT responsibilities ensures clear accountability when problems arise.
clause_13.validation_approach: Identify correspondent banking transactions by analyzing BIC patterns and product types. While correspondent relationship due diligence is primarily documented outside transaction data, the presence of certain BICs in transactions can indicate correspondent relationships that should have undergone enhanced due diligence. This is partially relevant as full validation requires access to correspondent banking agreements and due diligence documentation.

clause_14.title: Agency Arrangements
clause_14.description: Requirements for PSPs that use agents to provide cross-border money transfer services.

14.2.requirement: PSP shall not appoint an agent unless following requirements met:

requirements.14.2.a: Agency arrangement is documented in writing and approved by senior management
requirements.14.2.b: PSP takes appropriate steps to identify, assess and understand ML/TF risks particular to countries/jurisdictions that agent operates in
requirements.14.2.c: Agent is not one which PSPs have been specifically precluded by Authority from appointing
requirements.14.2.d: PSP includes all its agents in its AML/CFT programme and monitors them for compliance with programme

14.4.requirement: PSP shall maintain current list of its agents and make accessible to Authority and relevant authorities in countries/jurisdictions where agents operate, upon request

clause_14.summary: Agents extend the PSP's reach but also extend its ML/TF risk exposure. PSPs must conduct due diligence on agents, ensure they're included in AML/CFT programs, and monitor their compliance. Agents essentially act on behalf of the PSP, so the PSP bears responsibility for their actions.
clause_14.supplementary_info: Agents are commonly used in remittance businesses to provide convenient access points for customers. However, agents can be weak links if not properly controlled - they may have direct customer contact and handle cash without sufficient AML/CFT controls. The requirement for written agreements and senior management approval ensures that agent relationships are deliberate and controlled, not ad hoc arrangements.
clause_14.validation_approach: Agency arrangements and oversight are operational and contractual matters that cannot be validated from transaction data alone. Assessment requires reviewing agent agreements, monitoring records, and compliance documentation.

clause_17.title: Personal Data
clause_17.description: Provisions allowing PSPs to collect, use and disclose personal data for AML/CFT purposes, with certain access rights for individuals.

17.2.requirement: For purposes of complying with this Notice, PSP shall not be required to provide individual customers/appointed persons/connected parties/beneficial owners with:
exemptions: Access to personal data in possession or control of PSP
Information about ways personal data has been or may have been used or disclosed
Right to correct error or omission of personal data

17.3.requirement: PSP shall, as soon as reasonably practicable upon request, provide requesting individual with right to:
rights: Access specific types of personal data (full name including alias, unique ID number, residential address, date of birth, nationality, and other personal data provided by individual to PSP)
Correct error or omission in relation to those personal data types, provided PSP is satisfied there are reasonable grounds for request

17.4.requirement: For purposes of complying with this Notice, PSP may, whether directly or through third party, collect, use and disclose personal data without the respective individual's consent

clause_17.summary: This clause balances AML/CFT compliance needs with personal data protection. PSPs can collect and use personal data without consent for compliance purposes, but individuals retain certain access and correction rights. PSPs are not required to disclose how data is used (which would risk tipping off) but must provide access to core identity information.
clause_17.supplementary_info: The Personal Data Protection Act normally requires consent for data collection and use, but AML/CFT compliance is a legal obligation that overrides the consent requirement. The restriction on providing information about how data is used prevents inadvertent tipping-off - if a PSP told a customer their data was being analyzed for suspicious activity, this would defeat the purpose. However, individuals retain rights to access and correct their basic identity information to ensure accuracy.
clause_17.validation_approach: Personal data handling is a privacy and data governance matter that cannot be validated from transaction data. Assessment requires reviewing privacy policies, data protection impact assessments, and data subject request handling procedures.

clause_6.title: New Products, Practices and Technologies
clause_6.description: Requirements to assess ML/TF risks of new products, practices and technologies before launch, with special attention to anonymity-enhancing features.

6.1.requirement: PSP shall identify and assess ML/TF risks that may arise in relation to:
scope: Development of new products and new business practices, including new delivery mechanisms
Use of new or developing technologies for both new and existing products

6.2.requirement: PSP shall undertake risk assessments prior to launch or use of such products, practices and technologies (to extent use is permitted by this Notice), and shall take appropriate measures to manage and mitigate the risks

6.3.requirement: PSP shall, in complying with requirements of paragraphs 6.1 and 6.2, pay special attention to any new products, business practices, delivery mechanisms, and new or developing technologies that favour anonymity

clause_6.summary: Innovation must be balanced with risk management. PSPs must conduct ML/TF risk assessments before launching new products or adopting new technologies, with heightened scrutiny for anything that could enhance anonymity or obscure transaction trails.
clause_6.supplementary_info: Financial innovation often introduces new ML/TF risks - cryptocurrencies, mobile payments, peer-to-peer platforms, and other technologies can enable faster, more anonymous transactions. The requirement for prior risk assessment ensures that controls are designed into new products from the start, not retrofitted after problems emerge. Products favoring anonymity (e.g., prepaid cards, digital currencies, privacy-focused technologies) require special attention as they can be attractive to money launderers.
clause_6.validation_approach: Identify transactions involving complex products (product_complex=true) or virtual asset exposure (product_has_va_exposure=true). While new product risk assessments are documented outside transaction data, the presence of complex or emerging product types in transactions indicates that appropriate risk assessments should have been conducted. Flag new product_type or channel values that appear without corresponding risk documentation.

clause_3.title: Application of Notice
clause_3.description: Defines which payment service providers and products are subject to this Notice, including exemptions for certain low-risk products.

scope: Holders of licence under PS Act that carry on business of providing specified payment service
Persons exempt under section 13(1) of PS Act where such person offers specified product

account_issuance: Does not allow withdrawal of any cash
Does not allow refund exceeding S$100 in cash (except with ID verification and 5-year record keeping)
Does not allow currency equivalent or amount to exceed S$1,000
exemption_conditions.domestic_money_transfer: Business only involves payment for goods/services from identifiable source, or payment for goods/services not exceeding S$20,000, or payment from identifiable source not exceeding S$20,000
exemption_conditions.cross_border_money_transfer: Business only involves transactions for payment of goods/services funded from identifiable source

3.3.title: Exempted Products
3.3.requirement: Where PSP offers exempted product, does not need to comply with paragraphs 4.1(a), 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, and 15 of this Notice in relation to exempted product

exempted_product_definition.account_issuance: Product that does not allow cash withdrawal, allows refund exceeding S$100 only with ID verification and record-keeping, and cannot contain more than S$1,000
exempted_product_definition.domestic_money_transfer: Product satisfying at least two of: used only for goods/services payment; funded from identifiable source; transaction value does not exceed S$20,000
exempted_product_definition.cross_border_money_transfer: Product used only for goods/services payment and funded from identifiable source

clause_3.summary: The Notice applies broadly to payment service providers but recognizes that certain low-value, low-risk products warrant exemption from full CDD requirements. Exemptions are carefully scoped to ensure they only apply to genuinely low-risk scenarios with transaction limits and other controls.
clause_3.supplementary_info: Exempted products typically include low-value prepaid cards, stored-value facilities, and simple payment products with built-in limitations. The S$1,000 and S$20,000 thresholds recognize that lower-value transactions present lower ML/TF risk. The requirement for 'identifiable source' (defined in Payment Services Regulations as source that can be traced to an account or payment instrument) ensures some level of traceability even for exempted products. PSPs must still comply with suspicious transaction reporting even for exempted products.
clause_3.validation_approach: Identify transactions that may qualify as exempted products based on product_type and amount thresholds. Validate that transactions claiming exempted product status genuinely meet the criteria (e.g., payments for goods/services, amounts within limits). Flag any transactions where exempted product treatment is applied inappropriately (e.g., high-value transactions, unclear purposes that don't fit goods/services payment pattern).

clause_7.reason: Core CDD requirements - most comprehensive and directly validatable from transaction data. Critical for customer identification, verification, ongoing monitoring, and screening.

clause_15.reason: Wire transfer requirements (Travel Rule) - directly validatable from SWIFT and wire transfer data. Critical for cross-border transaction compliance.

clause_9.reason: Enhanced CDD for PEPs and high-risk customers - directly validatable from risk rating and PEP flags.

clause_11.reason: Cash restrictions and structuring detection - directly validatable from cash transaction data and aggregation patterns.
key_validation_points: Daily cash totals and transaction counts

clause_18.reason: Suspicious transaction reporting - directly validatable from suspicion flags and timing data.
key_validation_points: Timing of suspicion vs. transaction execution (18.2, 18.4)

medium_priority_clauses.clause_5: Risk assessment - partially validatable through customer risk ratings and risk-based measure application
medium_priority_clauses.clause_8: Simplified CDD - validatable through transaction thresholds and customer risk levels
medium_priority_clauses.clause_10: FX transactions - validatable where FX indicator and counterparty data available
medium_priority_clauses.clause_6: New products - partially validatable through product complexity flags

low_priority_clauses.clause_16: Record keeping - primarily systems/archival function, limited transaction-level validation
low_priority_clauses.clause_19: Internal policies/training - governance matters not validatable from transaction data
low_priority_clauses.clause_12: Third-party reliance - operational arrangements not in transaction data
low_priority_clauses.clause_13: Correspondent banking - enhanced due diligence documented outside transaction data
low_priority_clauses.clause_14: Agency arrangements - operational oversight not in transaction data
low_priority_clauses.clause_17: Personal data - privacy governance not validatable from transaction data
low_priority_clauses.clause_3: Application scope - partially validatable through product types and amounts
